text = Tomato Town

A co-worker was talking about an idea for a wrist-mounted computer she was thinking about. I saw http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1748 provided a decent platform for the idea. We just needed something to attach to it. Using jag's dovetail library (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10269) and a bit of experimentation, I made this. The dovetail is long enough to work with either one or two of the wrist mounts.

• Print (one or two) wrist mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1748).
  • Print this plate.
  • Slide the dovetail into the wrist mount (it should be a tight fit).
  • Use M3 screws and some plastic stand-offs to attach an Arduino (Uno or Duemilanove) with the matching holes.

comments.text: I just started testing a brass catcher for my AR-15 so this caught my eye.... does the Ruger really throw the shells that far forward?  I also want to make one for my Glock 9mm mounted in a similar fashion as this but I was going to use a bracket to position the shell catcher closer to the ejection port.  If your design uses less parts and works then props to you but does this actually catch your brass every time?  Also you refer to this as tactical rail mounted, does your Ruger have a front rail that is completely hidden by the brass catcher? I am thinking about buying one and was going to skip the front rail but it might be useful for things like this.
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text:
Dude, look a little closer. Think about it. That is not attached to the gun!
The author is showing you the inside of the item he created, including the rail mounts. The item would be spun 180* and attached to the rail on the TOP of the gun, then slid back until it is covering the ejection port. You can see the dovetail above the hole in the printed object. If the author showed it attached to the gun you couldn't see how it worked.
It would be insane to even consider for a second that this could literally catch randomly flung brass from this angle.
Those cartridges fling out many feet and all over the place.

title: Corner Structure Base Remix to make parametric for US or IE version

description.text:
I thought this design looked like a good idea, so decided to make it parametric in case I decide to print these. Since I have not printed this part out yet, I do not how well it actually works.

The variables you can easily change should be well commented. Only the 1st three variables you should need to change between the US & IE version of the MPCNC. You could use different numbers here, but you might have to change some other variables then.
You can vary the number of tightening bolt holes on each axis. 1,2 or 3 holes for Z & 1 or 2 holes on the X & Y.

Cyl_ID = 23.5; //IE version 25mm
Cyl_OD = 35.5; //IE version 37mm
Z_Cyl_Len = 40.75; //IE version 42.25mm

Small_Hole and M5Nut_OD variables are for the Bolt Tightening Hole & Nut trap. The other M5 variables relate to the 1 vertical hole thru the base.

Looks like the 4 pipes you cut for these will be 3.01"(76.5mm) shorter for US version & 78mm shorter for IE version than your MPCNC X & Y axis pipes, but verify that for yourself before cutting the pipes.

Thanks go to Arcade_Machine for this design idea. This is remixed from his part:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1469028
I was not able to get the thingiverse search to find this part to link it with the Remix source files. I will see if it works in the next day or so.

I enjoyed this little puzzle of making this design parametric. Let me know if you have any problems with variables not working correctly.

Update:
Rev5: Added option for 3 support holes to work table instead of just the 1 hole. The variable for that is: SupportHole_Qty. Set it to 1 or 3 for number of holes.

I also added another simple part for the horizontal pipes to rest on in case they sag a little on a long run. The openscad file for this is: HorizontalPipeRest.scad. I also included a stl file for the US & IE version.

comments.text: Happy that you like the idea and that it you've improved and extended to all over the world. It is my contribution. Thanks to people like Allted and as you
comments.author: Arcade_Machine

comments.text: Thanks for sharing your design.  One thing I was thinking about this afternoon was the horizontal pipes might need some little support half way since those pipes are about 6mm above the surface of the work table.

title: Retractable Photovoltaic System
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hello everybody, this is my prototype of a Retractable Photovoltaic System.

WHY I DID IT

2015 has been proclamed by UNESCO "International Year of Light".
It is " a global initiative adopted by the United Nations to raise awareness of how
optical technologies promote sustainable development and provide solutions to worldwide challenges in energy, education, agriculture, communications and health. "

University of Padua (02/11/2015) has launched a contest in order to increase awareness of worldwide issues among students from secondary schools.


So I decided to join the competition focusing on solar energy.

WHAT IS MY PROJECT ABOUT?
  • How Does It Work

It consists on six panels, arranged as the petals of a flower, and a mechanism (using servos) which allows them to move. My idea was to close the "petals" when there is bad weather (such as rain, snow, hail...), in order to avoid damages to the solar panels, and let them opened when the sun is shining.

  • What's the purpose

I've invented this "solar flower" to be placed in every kind of place you like (desert, hills, mountains...).
If we think of all those solar parks located in a place where snow fallings are not rare, we can notice that they lose a lot of energy because of the whole layer of snow, previously felt on the surface. An issue brought by this problem is the need of a daily routine maintenance, to make them working again (often very expensive).
So, I've focused my mind toward only one thing: increase efficiency and reduce maintenance costs

I have printed all the purple parts and most of the red ones. (Click on it)

  • Print in progress...

  • Some of the results

I have decided to use Arduino Nano for programming all the movements of the flower's servos and tree's ones. I have to say that the code is not so easy because I implemented arrays and functions, manual and automatic commands, but it was worth it!

I used a nunchuck controller for driving the servos (it communicates with Arduino through I2C Serial Interface):

Manual
You are able to move the flower in whichever position you want, opening and closing it.
Automatic Path
The flower follows a default path which consists on the positions of the sun during the day.

print_settings.Notes:: This is my first design uploaded, they all work great for me. If you run into any issues just contact me and I will work to resolve them for you ASAP.

description.text:
First change the parts orientation to how you would like to print it!

Yrodstock is for a stock I3, Yrod is for a mod set I am working on that uses offset bearing blocks to adapt a 3mm y carriage. You will need my bearing block file to use a 170mm spaced y carriage on the 140mm spaced wanhao.

Or you can just use my mounts and drill holes for any distance you desire. Important factor is clearance between carriage and printer. Yrod holder lets the z prod sit lower then stock.

My y rods were not even with the stock mounts and holes, deviations of 1mm easy. So I whipped up these little guys and they worked some magic!

I made a hole for a m3 screw to tighten on the rod that goes on top or bottom, but I have not used one yet! My rods fit very snug into the mounts.

You will need to mount these onto the rod ends, and then install your rod.

This printed to perfect dimensions for me, let me know if you have any questions!

Duplicator i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

.2-.3

30% and up

Notes:

I printed these fine in abs even bridging the m3 hole long ways, it should be an easy print.

author: cdr420

description.text: This is a redesign of the book ring I uploaded earlier. It is worn on the thumb and is designed to aid in one-handed book reading. It is slightly longer than the original, has rounded corners to protect your first editions, and was made a little more flexible by removing some plastic from the interior of the wings. I have provided two models; one with "EX LIBRIS" printed on the wings, and one with blank wings that you can personalize with any CAD software if you wish. Both OBJ and STL files are provided. As with the first model, the ring may be worn with the words facing the book, or facing the reader. Comfort should dictate the manner of use. I have included pictures of the "EX LIBRIS" model. Please excuse the hangnails adorning my cuticles. I have only printed this in ABS, but PLA should work fine. I used medium quality print standards for this print (0.2mm layers) and it turned out great. This is not a piece with tight tolerances so just about any print parameters should result in a useable print. As stated in the original project, this was inspired by an Instructable (http://www.instructables.com/id/How-make-a-reader-ring-with-Sugru/). Happy reading!

author: cerberus333

description.text:
Are you thinking it's time for some shields to protect that temperamental ABS print you've tried several times without success?? Or, do you want to keep that cat away from batting at the hot end? Either way, here's a low-cost solution I baked up (literally) for your SeeMeCNC Rostock Max.

I included v1 of the brackets since one of the images below shows them and someone may be interested in ones that are almost indestructible for other applications.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You can use any plastic. I was testing some Phileex PLA.
The brackets snap on and the shield sits in the groove. I didn't use any adhesive so I can remove the shields easily. If the effector bumps against the shield they will flex (by design).

All in Tinkercad.

What I've been using for quite some time. Various iterations being inspected by the Boss!

Are you ready to bend some polycarbonate?? Oh yeah! What's Needed
  • (3) printed brackets
  • (3) .093 11X14 sheets of polycarbonate (e.g. Lexan)
  • (3) non-stick, oven safe baking sheets (I used these grill sheets)
  • (1) 18x36 joint sheet used in hvac duct work
  • (1) oven and various oven safe dishes
The goods. Prepare the furnace!

Some research reveals 300F for several hours (actually was little over an hour for me). Remove all the shelves leaving the bottom one and place the metal sheet in an arch supported by a stack of oven safe bowls.

This should work, right? Prepare the poly sandwich!

Remove the protective plastic from the poly sheets and lay them on top of each other with a grill sheet between each pane.

All ready to bake! Bake it!

Lay the sandwich evenly on the arch and start cranking the oven to 300F. I checked on the poly every 30 min until I was happy with the form.

Looks about centered. Hey, I think it's doing something after 30 minutes! It's only been an hour! Ok, that's enough, look at the middle starting to rise! DING!

What I thought was going to take several hours finished between 1 hour and 1 hour, 30 min. Your results may vary. Turn the oven off, leave the door open and let it cool for at least 30 min before removing.

Something to consider.

The grill sheets worked great; unfortunately, they left a slight imprint on the poly so if you look close enough you can see the fiber weave. Since the shields are seldom clean from the hairspray it doesn't bother me.

title: Binary Epoch Clock Kit LED Alignment Tool

description.text: The hardest part of assembling our Binary Epoch Clock Kit is keeping the LEDs aligned and all pointing the same direction. So we designed this simple tool to help out with that process. Not only does it help keep all of the LEDs aligned, but makes soldering them in much, much quicker. Normally, per our instructions, you would solder the LEDs in 4 at a time. But with this, simply insert all of the LEDs and then fit this jig onto the front of the clock PCB. It will hold all of the LEDs in place and correctly aligned while the board is flipped over. No need to even bend the leads over, to hold them in place, before soldering!

Print with low preset:
  • 0.3mm layer height
  • 2 shells
  • 10% infill

description.text: Simple Endstop Switch Placeholder
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jji5ZLiHbOm

The drawing files were created to tell a laser cutter to laser cut marble track spacer out of a 12" x 12" sheet of birch plywood. These spacers are designed to hold two 1/4-inch ice-maker tubs in place and exasperated for a 3/4 inch marble. The spacers also have a companion bracket which allows the track designer to attach the track to an upright 3/8-inch dowel structure.

The "small" file is set up to cut 60 sets of spacers and clips from a 12" x 24" sheet of 1/8" Baltic Birch for 1/2" marbles.

A close friend recently purchased a P30SK pistol, and found that the handle was a little shorter than he preferred after firing the sub compact. Given that we couldn't find any add-on's from HK to extend the magazine, i made these for him. he prefers the "thin" extension, as his hands are a bit smaller. i will upload some pictures of it on his firearm later.

i left the back flat (where the "HK" is) in order to give a flat portion for print. this is the best orientation, so that the mag spring doesn't de-laminate printed layers.

description.text:
I took old photos of Thomas Edison and Nikola Tesla, both prolific inventors with some controversy between them.and extruded them to 3D.  They are meant to be viewed from the back flat side with light coming through them.  That is why the text is backwards.  This was done with a feature in Netfabb Private and Pro.  
Sorry about the size of the files, they can probably be decimated down.

Just print it flat side down with 1-2 shells and 10% fill in a white or light opaque material so light can pass through.  You view it from the flat side.  Print flat side down.  It will look light a flat piece of plastic until the light hits it just right.

comments.text: Nikola Tesla, was a great scientist, theoretical thinker, and inventor, but a poor business person.  He died poor not because people stole his ideas but because he canceled the royalty agreement he had with George Westinghouse when Westinghouse was facing financial difficulties.  If he did not do that, he'd have been a wealthy man.  He ran out of money building his Long Island Tower to develop radio, Westinghouse couldn't or wouldn't give him additional funds and Marconi went on to develop radio.  Westinghouse paid for Tesla's room and board at a NY hotels for the years before he died.

comments.text: Edison did not kill an elephant.  It's a myth most recently promoted by Wired magazine in a poorly researched article.  Yes, Edison was in the name of the power company that supplied the power, but Edison had no ownership or interest in the company. In fact a combination of drugging, electrocuting, and strangling the electrocuted elephant was viewed as a more acceptable means of killing this elephant that had killed three people than the original plan which was to hang it.  The ASPCA intervened in the hanging plan which led to the lectrocution.

comments.author: agnoses

comments.text: Thanks, for the input, I was already planning on doing Tesla next.  As for Edison, yes, he was wrong about DC vs AC.  And yes, he did not invent the light bulb. He invented a commercially viable light bulb.
comments.author: MakerBeck

comments.text:
Looks nice, however I don't quite agree with your 'Great inventor' label, Edison was certainly not without his faults. A good inventor certainly but also a ruthless and at times unethical business man, he certainly played a big part in destroying Tessla's reputation and his position as inventor of the light bulb is vastly exaggerated (it was patented 50yrs prior to Edison's work and Edison's patents were challenged in the UK and US and he lost.).
A great example of the history books been written by the victor, and certainly Edison won many of the patent/invention battles he fought, whether he chose to go about that in an honorable way is up for debate. I would regard him as a good example of a successful entrepreneur, however not as a role model.
Having said that, nice bit of 3D work. :)

comments.text: Thingiverse assumes 3D printer orientation: which was developed out of milling/CNC orientation. So Z is height rather than depth. 3D animation assumes x and y are the screen plane rather than the build plane. That said, reorienting it and centering it takes like 2 seconds, so there is no fuss. You can open it in ReplicatorG, reorient it, and resave it to create a Thingiverse-friendly STL!

author: cushwa

description.text:
This is a customizable contact card for your braille-literate colleagues, friends and loved ones. It is very similar to the letter text business contact card maker:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1473900

To do this from the comfort of your own computer, you will need to download these three files:

BrailleContactCard.scad
Write.scad
braille.dxf

Place them in the same folder before opening BrailleContactCard.scad (using OpenSCAD). From there, modify the code to your liking, render and then generate the .stl file. Hopefully you know what to do from there.

As always, if you found this useful, please share and be sure to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

description.text:
First off this is totally cosmetic and will not make your prints any better. With the extruder stepper motor rotated and the wires behind this I can get the full 180mm Z-height (see picture) even with LED lights installed under the top of my gantry. This will only work in conjunction with my drag link relocation bracket:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1448260

My original shroud was designed for my setup with a single X-axis upper block. I added a second STL file with more clearance to accommodate the stock dual block setup. Sorry for the inconvenience this might have caused. Additionally you need to rotate the extruder stepper motor 45 degrees so the wires are facing the rear of the printer.

Credit for the Wanhao Rhino logo goes out to barbet:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:852569

Instructions:

  1. Print it
  2. Clip it on
  3. Profit

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aY208NVPVYT
A computer controlled orbit simulator. It could also be used for non-elliptical paths. It was built to let students practice photometry in a physics lab setting. http://youtu.be/okWp-dryx_8

Mill the dxf parts out of 12mm or 1/2" flatstock. Pockets for steppers and bearings are 6mm or 1/4" deep. The legs are just 2x4's. Hardware:
Old work round box
Light socket
Big bulb
M8x50 button head cap screw (5/16"-2" will work)
M8 nut (5/16" will work)
M8 washer (1/2" will work)
2 608 skate bearings
8 M3x10
2 Nema17 steppers
Control board w/ 2 stepper drivers
Power supply for control board
2 6" turn tables http://www.homedepot.com/p/Shepherd-6-in-Lazy-Susan-Turntable-9548/100180572#.UivaAMasiSo Drive Gears Assembly:
Tap the printed parts into the matching gears. Install steppers onto orrery. They won't be able to be installed after you push on the gears. To push on the gears you have to soften the plastic. Place the gears in an oven at the lowest setting. Take out at minute interval and tap the plastic part on a hard surface. A couple minutes after the sound changes to a dull thud you are ready to press the gears on. (If you aren't careful, you can severely deform the plastic if it is left unattended.) Gear Plate Assembly:
The only thing I left out is access holes so you can screw down the turn tables. I am going to claim that is because I didn't want to stick you with a specific turn table. You can borrow the electronics and some steppers from a 3D printer. Modify the firmware so 100mm of virtual travel corresponds to 1 rotation of a big gear. Use the python program I uploaded to make gcode files.

remixed_from.author: TanyaAkinora
remixed_from.title: Halbach array holder for NMR spectrometer.

title: Halbach Array Holder for NMR Spectrometer - Remix for K&J; Magnets

description.text:
A remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:942257 designed to fit off-the-shelf magnets available from K&J Magnetics. In particular, to fit the radially-aligned BX066 1" x 3/8" x 3/8" N42 magnets. These magnets gave a center field of ~0.4 T.

Magnet holes have been shrunk to create very tight tolerances for the magnets to stop them from rotating, and I created a placement for a center magnet. In making past Halbachs, I found it much easier to insert and align outer magnets if a center magnet was in place aligned with the final field. I also expanded the NMR sample holder and included an *.stl with supports already included.

Have not yet printed and tested, although am planning on it soon.

print_settings.Notes:: When I decided to print it out, I firstly downloaded pdb file from RCSB. And then I put it into VMD software to do some selections and modifications. After you selected parts of it, you should modify some resolution of sphere---mine is about 15 and regulate its size---again mine is about 2.5. And after that, you should scale up its size to 4.0 to avoid being too small in practice. And then, you can render your file into stl form and convert it into tinkercad. After that, you should first select and modify you angle of the molecule in tinkercad and download it in form of stl file, putting in into makerbot to check it out whether its size is suitable for being printed. If it's okay, congratulations! Then you should go back to tinkercad and add some supports of it. Pay attention! When you add some supports for it, you should be careful of height of sticks. That is to say, some of your sticks would be too tall to hold up the ball above it by itself----and this is why my print fell down. To address this problem, you should add some rafts to strengthen these sticks---and you can see I have modified my model by adding some rafts to it. When you get all this done, you can convert it into makerbot again, and wait for it being printed. By the way, printing time may take you 3-4 hours. Good luck!

description.text:

It can be used to control growth of gram positive bacteria by binding tightly to D-alanine-D-alanine peptide which is an important structure for one peptide attaching to another to block the ability to form the crosslink.

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes:

When I decided to print it out, I firstly downloaded pdb file from RCSB. And then I put it into VMD software to do some selections and modifications. After you selected parts of it, you should modify some resolution of sphere---mine is about 15 and regulate its size---again mine is about 2.5. And after that, you should scale up its size to 4.0 to avoid being too small in practice. And then, you can render your file into stl form and convert it into tinkercad. After that, you should first select and modify you angle of the molecule in tinkercad and download it in form of stl file, putting in into makerbot to check it out whether its size is suitable for being printed. If it's okay, congratulations! Then you should go back to tinkercad and add some supports of it. Pay attention! When you add some supports for it, you should be careful of height of sticks. That is to say, some of your sticks would be too tall to hold up the ball above it by itself----and this is why my print fell down. To address this problem, you should add some rafts to strengthen these sticks---and you can see I have modified my model by adding some rafts to it. When you get all this done, you can convert it into makerbot again, and wait for it being printed. By the way, printing time may take you 3-4 hours. Good luck!

If you don't have (or use) a light meter, Richard Koolish's clever mechanical calculator can help you select an exposure time for tiny aperture (pinhole) cameras, which require lengthy exposure times. These disks are designed around Ilford's version:
http://www.ilfordphoto.com/Webfiles/2011106152612113.pdf
Which is attributed to Mr. Koolish, but freely downloadable (and included in the source files for this thing). ...but there are others:
http://www.rahji.com/pdf/koolish.pdf http://static.freewebstore.org/templates//79100/myimages/pinhole_camera_exposre_calculator.pdf http://www.rahji.com/wordpress/2007/05/12/pinhole-exposure-times/

The large disk is oriented to fit (barely) on a 6x6 print bed if you have one of the smaller printers. Alternately, you could experiment with scaling down the PDF and the 3D-printed parts. Assembly should be obvious, but here's how I did it.
  • Print the disks; print the calculator page.
  • Dress the center holes of the 3d printed parts with a 3mm / 1/8-inch bit.
  • Cut out the paper disks (with a hole compass, if you have one). Don't amputate the arrow!
  • Smooth the top surfaces of the disks (sandpaper / file)
  • Carefully glue the paper disks on the smoothest side of of the 3D printed disks. I used Elmer's spray adhesive, which gives you some time to scootch and twist the paper precisely into position. Align the pointer on the paper with the tab on the middle disk; align the ISO windows on the top disks, but don't cut out the window on the paper until they are glued together. Yes, I know the windows are different shapes.
  • Clean the paper from the center holes, and assemble the disks with a 3mm / 1/8-inch bolt, locknut, and washers.
    • A handy lanyard hole lets you hang the calculator around your neck or from your tripod, keeping the device at ready. This calculator does not factor reciprocity failure into the exposure calculation - a necessary lengthening of exposure time to get a desired exposure, and is a unique property of your particular film choice. More info:
    http://www.geofflawrence.com/reciprocity_failure.html Google "reciprocity failure for _myfilm". The Pinhole Designer program ( http://www.pinhole.cz/en/pinholedesigner/ ) can generate a corrected exposure chart for many different films, but then you wouldn't need this calculator... Shoot some pinhole photos!

Sand down and use epoxy to fill as desired to prepare parts. Glue together the upper and lower gun mounts sand as necessary. Dry fit upper and lower bodies along with gun mounts, file and sand as needed to fit and glue the upper and lower bodies with the gun mount in the proper hole keeping glue away from the gun mount unless you want it locked in one position. author: Simhopp

print_settings.Notes:: PLA is OK for use on my printer, as the screws that run up to the heated bed barely get warm.

title: Printer Bed Level Adjuster Nut Keeper for Geeetech Prusa I3

description.text:
Update 10/9/17 , 12/3/16 See below.

The bed leveling adjustment screws on my Prusa I3 printer use a cap screw, spring and a wingnut. In order to adjust the screw, you have hold one part while turning the other. This part and a 3 mm hex nut replaces the wingnut and allows you to adjust the bed leveling screws using a hex driver on the cap screw without having to hold onto a second part.

There are a couple versions. The one with the long arms is the easiest to print and install. The one with one shortened arm was required to avoid interference with the frame and collars on the smooth rods of the Y axis at the back of the printer. The short arm lies along the X axis, the long arm along the Y axis.

The keeper with the short arm needs a mirror image copy along with the one shown in order to fit on both sides of the print carriage. Repetier and probably others will easily generate a mirror image copy.

The keeper with the short arm requires support, which can be difficult to remove from the hex nut recess. The one with the long arms requires no support.

Why it looks the way it does:
On my Printer, the hole pattern of the carriage does not match the hole pattern of the bed heater, therefore the adjusting screws are at an angle. The cone provides a pivot point to accommodate the misalignment of the screw connecting the two pieces. The arms and the pads that protrude from them press against the print bed carriage and prevent the nut from turning. The thickness push-out of the pad at the end of the arm provides some tension to keep the nut from turning if the hole pattern is such that both arms don't contact the carriage.

UPDATE 10/9/17 NOTE: i HAVEN'T PRINTED THESE, SO IF YOU RUN INTO A PROBLEM, ADD A COMMENT. Add a comment anyway I and others would like to hear about your experience.
I added a version without the cone and containing a cavity for inserting a nut during printing. To insert the nut, you need to stop the printer before it prints the layer that closes the cavity, and insert a 3 mm nut. This requires a patch in the G-code, unless your control software accommodates pauses. I'm familiar with two types of G-Code patches that are inserted at the start of the layer that closes the cavity. The first is the M600 command. If your printer firmware supports this command, executing it will cause the printer to move to a park location, and wait while you insert a nut into the cavity and then press a button on the printer to continue. The second is the addition of a command to move the carriage aside, and then a pause command to stop the printer. The G-Code for moving the carriage is G1 X150. If you use Repetier Host, the pause command (on a new line) is @pause. If you use something different, I don't have any suggestions.

UPDATE 1/8/18 AN OPINION : If you use the two suggestions below plus add an optical sensor in the Z axis (see my THING for the Geeetech I3) you will have, IMO, the best solution to the bed leveling problem short of an auto-level system. And this is without the expense and potential headaches of installing a new hardware system and firmware changes. With these three relatively simple upgrades, I find that I almost never have to touch the bed adjustment screws, unless there is some mechanical change or trauma. FWIW, I tend to set the Z home position somewhat tighter than usually recommended, so the first layer is over-extruded, but has a good bond to the bed.

UPDATE 12/3/16
There are a couple things that can theoretically have a positive effect on the bed adjustment and are easy to do, and I believe it's worth the effort. Unless I change a nozzle or other mechanical changes, I rarely have to adjust the bed, and that's a lot different than the way it was when I first assembled the printer.

The changes include: 1. polishing the ends of the springs so they don't have any wind-up torque stored during adjustment.

  1. Adding some locktite (blue) to the screw thread to discourage drift.

The ends of the wire spring are cut off square, and this leaves an edge that can dig into the material they rest upon and possibly store some energy when the screw is rotated. Polishing them with a fine stone or file removes the edge and the tendency for wind-up.

Adding some blue locktite to the screw makes the screw less likely to turn in the nut unless you are the one turning it. Apply only a small amount of Loctite. Let it set a couple days and then turn the screw to break the hold of the Loctite. Hold onto the keeper to prevent it turning (and breaking) when you first turn it. Locktite adds enough stickiness that it won't move unless some force is applied.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3 Layer height or less

Infill:

10% or more

Notes:

The 3D inspector in Sketchup does not find a structural error with the file, but Repetier/Slic3r says that the .STL file is not Manifold. The good news is that it may print OK anyway. I probably messed it up in one of the tries to pull up the conical shape or when I added the extension arms. I couldn't find the problem, but it didn't cause any trouble when I printed them.

Print them with the hex nut side down. I didn't use support on the one with the long arms, and the hex nut cavity will take some clean up, as a few threads may fall into the cavity before it becomes covered completely. The one with the short arm requires support, and removing the support that is placed inside the hex nut cavity requires a knife and some patience.

PLA is OK for use on my printer, as the screws that run up to the heated bed barely get warm.

The hex nut cavity and the hole for the 3 mm screw are likely going to be a tight fit. Use a file or a 3 mm screw to clean up the hole, and a file or other sharp tool to clean up the hex cavity. It is preferable to press the nut into the piece, but if it prints too small, you may want to scale up the X Y dimensions a couple percent before printing, You can use a 9 mm socket and a vice to press the nut into the hole, once you remove most of the interference.

I found that the cone could be lowered a bit with a file and it makes installation easier. Also, the top inside edge of the ends of the arms can be beveled slightly with a file and it makes it easier to fit it around the carriage.

Depending on your bed, the arms that keep the nut from turning may be deflected slightly to fit on the bed, or you can file the pads on the extension arms to make them fit better, if they are sprung too much. If they fit the carriage loosely, you can use tape or other spacer to tighten up the fit to the carriage. It's not important, but IMO it is preferable to having the nut move when adjusting.
Sketchup Make 2016.

author: Hakeem21

title: Arduino (RAMPS) mount for Prusa / Mendel with accessories holes

description.text:
I didn't find any Arduino MEGA 2560 (& RAMPS) mounting for the bars of a Prusa Mendel that I liked so....I made my own. I've been trying to get rid of all the wood on my Prusa Mendel (Makergear) and this was the last piece to replace. Hope someone finds the useful. Features: Simple design, but somewhat pretty
Has a side with holes (7mm apart) that can be used for accessories or to zip tie cables.
Can be installed anywhere, bar clamps are only on one side.
Somewhat parametric, you can change some stuff in the openSCAD.
Print and mount your Arduino board on your Mendel.

title: LRC Race X drone camera mount

description.text:
These are camera mounts designed to fit the 'LRC Race X' racing drone frame from
https://www.liftrc.com/lrc-racex
Stock standoffs with this frame are 20mm and 35mm, I included a few versions of the mount for guys using lower 15mm standoffs as well.
At the moment two cameras are being supported, more will be added as more micro cameras are made available.
Pico V2 (Foxeer XAT520) - https://www.liftrc.com/foxeer-xat520-super-mini-520tvl-fpv-camera
Lumenier SMC-600 - https://www.liftrc.com/lumenier-smc-600-super-mini-cased-600tvl-wide-angle
Micro 600TVL- http://www.paragonuav.com/micro-600tvl-110-fpv-camera/
I can further edit this camera mount for different camera angles etc. Let me know if you have any ideas.
Eric

Insert 6x13mm V-Roller bearing and secure with a M4x15mm machine screw or similar.

Place O-rings in the depressions under neath the part then slide onto the Universal spool holder.

Step 3

Cut 2 pieces of foam/sponge into 25x25x5mm squares and place them in the filament cleaner holder then snap the cover onto the filament cleaner holder.
